**[Andrés Cruz](https://arcruz0.github.io/), Senior Research Analyst**
<br>Andrés Cruz is a PhD student at the Department of Government and an MS student in the Department of Statistics and Data Sciences at the University of Texas at Austin. He studies political methodology with applications in comparative politics. His research interests include data quality, measurement error, and computational social science. He received a BA and MA in Political Science from Pontificia Universidad Católica de Chile.

<br><br><img align="left" src="images/Elkins.png" width="210" height="200">
**[Zachary Elkins](https://liberalarts.utexas.edu/government/faculty/elkinszs), Co-Director**
<br>Zachary Elkins is an associate professor in the University of Texas at Austin’s Department of Government. His research focuses on issues of democracy, institutional reform, research methods, and national identity, with an emphasis on cases in Latin America. Much of his research is on the origins and consequences of national constitutions. With Tom Ginsburg (University of Chicago), he co-directs both the [Comparative Constitutions Project](https://comparativeconstitutionsproject.org/), an NSF-funded initiative to understand the causes and consequences of constitutional choices, and [Constitute](https://www.constituteproject.org/), which provides resources for constitutional drafters. He earned his BA from Yale University, an MA from UT Austin, and his PhD from the University of California, Berkeley.

<br><img align="left" src="images/Gardner.png" width="210" height="200">
**Roy Gardner, Co-Director**
<br>Roy Gardner is a data scientist focused on natural language processing, machine learning, and data analysis. He is a researcher for the [Comparative Constitutions Project](https://comparativeconstitutionsproject.org/) and consultant at the PeaceRep consortium led by the University of Edinburgh Law School. He founded the digital services partnership Ontonomic and the digital services company Psycle Interactive where he developed the semantic web technology supporting [Constitute](https://www.constituteproject.org/)’s interactive web tools, linked data, and concept analysis. He has a BSc in Experimental Psychology and PhD in Neuroscience, with post-doctoral work on algorithms for automatic speech recognition and experimental studies of human speech perception, funded by the UK Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council and UK Medical Research Council.

<br><img align="left" src="images/Martin.png" width="210" height="200">
**[Matthew Martin](https://mattjamesmartin.github.io/), Senior Research Analyst**
<br>Matthew Martin is a PhD student in the University of Texas at Austin’s Department of Government. His fields of study are public law and comparative politics, and his research interests include public participation in constitution-making, Latin American politics, indigenous constitutionalism, and immigration politics. He first worked as a graduate research assistant for the [Comparative Constitutions Project](https://comparativeconstitutionsproject.org/) during the summer of 2021 and has remained involved in CCP projects since. His dissertation examines the use of public consultation in constitution-making by authoritarian regimes. Previously, he was a full-time legal assistant in family and humanitarian immigration law. He received a dual-degree BA in Legal Studies and Political Science from the University of Massachusetts at Amherst.

<br><img align="left" src="images/Moran.png" width="210" height="200">
**[Ashley Moran](https://liberalarts.utexas.edu/government/faculty/am49396), Co-Director**
<br>Ashley Moran is a political scientist focused on comparative constitutional development, court elaboration of new constitutions, and divided societies. She is research director for the [Comparative Constitutions Project](https://comparativeconstitutionsproject.org/), a lecturer in UT Austin’s Government Department, and a distinguished scholar at UT’s Robert Strauss Center for International Security and Law. Previously, she worked on democratic, legal, and constitutional reform in Central Asia, the Caucasus, and the Middle East for the National Democratic Institute for International Affairs and the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe. She has an MA in Comparative Law and Development Economics from the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy and a PhD in Government from UT-Austin.
